message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden pain and instability after being taken down suggest a possible anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear. Anterior translation of the tibia relative to the femur is a common finding in patients with ACL tears. Laxity to valgus stress is more commonly seen in patients with medial collateral ligament (MCL) tears. Clicking and locking of the joint with motion is commonly seen in patients with meniscal tears. Posterior translation of the tibia relative to the femur is more commonly seen in patients with posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) tears.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury, sudden pain, swelling, and feeling unstable when bearing weight suggest a possible ACL tear. Among the options, anterior translation of the tibia relative to the femur is the most likely finding in a patient with an ACL tear. Laxity to valgus stress suggests a possible MCL tear, clicking and locking of the joint with motion suggests a possible meniscus tear, and posterior translation of the tibia relative to the femur suggests a possible PCL tear.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury and the feeling of instability suggests an ACL tear. Anterior translation of the tibia relative to the femur is a common physical exam finding in patients with ACL tears, indicating that the tibia is not being held in place by the ACL when pulled forward. Laxity to valgus stress is a finding in patients with MCL tears. Clicking and locking of the joint with motion suggests a meniscal tear. Posterior translation of the tibia relative to the femur is a finding in patients with PCL tears.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury and the presentation suggest a possible anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury. Anterior translation of the tibia relative to the femur is a hallmark finding of an ACL tear. Laxity to valgus stress is a finding in medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury, clicking and locking of the joint with motion is seen in meniscal injuries, and posterior translation of the tibia relative to the femur is associated with posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury.

We refer to medical textbooks for help. The description of the mechanism of injury and subsequent instability of the knee suggests a possible anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear, which would result in anterior translation of the tibia relative to the femur upon physical examination. Laxity to valgus stress is more indicative of a medial collateral ligament (MCL) tear, while clicking and locking of the joint with motion suggests a meniscal tear. Posterior translation of the tibia relative to the femur is more indicative of a posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) tear.

Anterior translation of the tibia relative to the femur is the most likely physical exam finding in this patient. Laxity to valgus stress may indicate a MCL injury, clicking and locking may indicate a meniscal tear, and posterior translation of the tibia may indicate a PCL injury.

Anterior translation of the tibia relative to the femur is a common finding in patients with an ACL tear. Laxity to valgus stress may indicate a collateral ligament injury. Laxity to valgus stress suggests an injury to the medial collateral ligament, clicking and locking suggests a meniscal injury, and posterior translation of the tibia relative to the femur suggests a posterior cruciate ligament injury.

Anterior translation of the tibia relative to the femur is a classic finding in patients with an ACL tear. Laxity to valgus stress is more commonly seen with MCL (medial collateral ligament) injuries. Clicking and locking of the joint with motion is often seen with meniscal injuries. Posterior translation of the tibia relative to the femur is more indicative of PCL (posterior cruciate ligament) injuries.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanism of injury suggests a possible anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear. Anterior translation of the tibia relative to the femur is a positive Lachman’s test, which indicates an ACL tear. Laxity to valgus stress is seen in medial collateral ligament (MCL) tear, clicking and locking of the joint with motion is seen in meniscal injury, and posterior translation of the tibia relative to the femur is seen in posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) tear.
